qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I use my phone mostly for WhatsApp to talk to my sister and niece, and to take orders from customers. Sometimes, I watch stitching videos on YouTube. I don’t use many apps.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, my children use it sometimes to watch cartoons, and my husband uses it when his phone is charging. I don’t mind, but I ask them not to open my messages.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: WhatsApp and camera. I like taking photos of dresses I stitch to show customers. I don’t really know what these apps collect. I don’t think about that.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like to access your location or camera, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I just press ‘allow’ if it is needed. I don’t understand what those things mean. Sometimes I ask my niece.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my niece or son-in-law says it’s okay, I use it. I don’t install things by myself. I don’t trust unknown apps.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Yes, I deleted some voice messages from a customer once because I didn’t want my husband to get confused or feel bad.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I remove my SIM and memory card. I also delete some WhatsApp chats. But I don’t know how to remove everything.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, my niece helps me. I trust her. I feel a little shy if she sees some personal photos, so I tell her first.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I prefer speaking in person. I don’t share personal matters over phone or WhatsApp.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Sometimes, yes. I use names or short words with my sister that others won’t understand.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how. I always ask others for help.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know these things.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I stop and show it to my son or niece.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think maybe it needs it to work. I never thought about whether they are storing or sharing it.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, I waited for my niece to delete some things before giving it to the shop.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Once a boy opened the gallery and said ‘Ma’am, your memory is full.’ I didn’t like it.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No, it’s too confusing for me. And if my phone locks, I can’t open it again.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t know. I only use what others help me install.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My niece or sometimes my neighbor’s son.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, they say don’t click strange links or accept unknown calls.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I will delete some chats and remove the SIM card. Then I give it to the repair shop.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If a message comes, I quickly open it or tell my husband, ‘Don’t read, it’s stitching order.’
scenarios.New App Requesting Permissions: I won’t install it unless someone I trust tells me it’s okay.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I am the elderly one, I think! Others help me.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I return it without touching anything.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I will give it only after someone deletes my things.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: If I deleted photos and they come back, I would be very scared.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: Never used that. I only use my mobile data.
scenarios.Lottery Call: Yes, I got one. I told my husband, and he said to block the number.
scenarios.Friend Needs Help: I would ask my husband first. If we can help, we will.
